title: Matthew Rocklin
description: Personal site of Matthew Rocklin - thoughts on open source, startups, and engineering

items.title: Working Notes
items.content_html: I work in the Python data ecosystem, building tools like Dask and Coiled. I write about the technical and human aspects of this work.

items.title: We're All Beginners Again
items.content_html: Everyone feels behind on AI, but no one is ahead. That shared beginner status is what makes this moment so fun.

items.title: Introducing Claude Chic
items.content_html: A Claude code drop-in with updated UX and multi-agent support

items.title: AI Zealotry
items.content_html: Senior engineers are best positioned to benefit from AI. We're good enough to avoid slop, and there's so much we can accomplish. I wouldn't go back.

items.title: Twitter, LinkedIn, and Failing in Public
items.content_html: LinkedIn shows only the final act. We connect to heroes during their struggles, not their victories. The solution: fail heroically in public.

items.title: I Walked across Spain
items.content_html: Reflections from 27 days and 500 miles across Spain. The overlapping physical, social, cultural, and spiritual layers that make this pilgrimage meaningfully different.

items.title: Thoughtful Professional Writing
items.content_html: Speaking flows at the speed of thought. Writing forces you to organize first. This is hard on you but easy on your reader.

items.title: Transactionalism vs Respect
items.content_html: "Can I ask for your help?" makes me feel like a person who helps people. "I'll pay you back" makes me feel like I'm trading favors. Incentives feel transactional.

items.title: Hammers and Nailguns
items.content_html: A nailgun puts nails into wood. A hammer whacks things. Simple tools with humble opinions are more versatile than specialized ones.

items.title: Python Support is Socially Complex
items.content_html: When a Python workflow fails, most of the work is diagnosing whose fault it is. The ecosystem's distributed ownership means no one has clear responsibility.

items.title: Cloud Computing is Broken
items.content_html: What hunger am I seeing on the ground? Boring shit. People struggle most with the basics of cloud computing. The promise remains undelivered.

items.title: Venting and Constructive Communication
items.content_html: Constructive conversation and venting differ by one question: "Will these words help me achieve my goal?" If no, we're probably venting.

items.title: SatCamp Retrospective
items.content_html: Satellite imagery's potential is incredible, but companies in this space are struggling. An outsider's first impressions from an unconference in Boulder.

items.title: How I Almost Quit My Job, and How Being Selfish Saved Me
items.content_html: When a small amount of your work helps others a great deal, of course you sacrifice. You'd be a monster not to. But your ego can fade in service of your project.

items.title: What Does Pangeo 2.0 Look Like?
items.content_html: In 2018 we unveiled a new architecture for scalable cloud Python. It was great, but also fragile and limited. What comes next?

items.title: Usage Based Pricing
items.content_html: It was good for a while but became a dead end. The pros, cons, and alternatives for capturing value while making customers feel good about paying.

items.title: Feedback
items.content_html: Open source code review taught me to give intense, detailed feedback. Then I became a manager and learned why that doesn't always translate.

items.title: Hiring Sales
items.content_html: We fired the sales team when our product was bad. Now it's good. Finding the right early sales hire is an interesting challenge.

items.title: Reddit, Twitter, and LinkedIn Comparison
items.content_html: I pushed the same message to Reddit, Twitter, LinkedIn, and Mastodon and tracked views and engagement. Reddit won by a mile.
